Andy,

Sure, I understand it was just an example.  I went with the example =

just for illustration, but let me give a shot at a more general 
answer:

=
I think the most general answer is that to the extent inputs and 
outputs r=
eally are apples and oranges there is still valuable 
information that can =
be included with respect to how they are 
separately arranged.  It is not o=
nly the relationship of inputs to 
outputs, but the relations of inputs to =
each other (and outputs to 
each other) that is potentially valuable.  

On=
 the other hand, I don't think inputs and outputs are really often 
going t=
o truly be apples and oranges since both normally will be at 
least about t=
he same world, i.e. what I see in the world vs. what I 
do in the world; so=
 there is an inherent conceptual relationship 
between them in most context=
s.  While it is possible to pose a 
problem in a way that removes some of t=
hat relationship (such as in 
your example), it should normally be possible=
 to recast the problem 
at least in part to restore it.  That is, there is =
more than one way 
to pose a problem from a geometric standpoint.  In gener=
al if the 
inputs and outputs are both about the same world, then some meth=
od 
is probably available.

At the same time, even in cases where there is =
really no 
relationship whatsoever, there is still utility in arranging the=
 
inputs and outputs separately in ways that correspond to their 
respectiv=
e geometric contexts.

ken

condition

ormation" associated with a substrate

 For

t field 
(where

output 
field

here?).

t 
allow

t

2D,

proximities

e cases it is implicit.  
For

t node and a 2D sheet of

ake a target

hat case you just

of it.  In 
such

proximity

ithin 
the

re 
also

e 
that 
> > nearness even though it is not explicitly provided as input.  =

enario
